Award.AwardTitle: TiPi: Engineering & Engineering Technology Transfer Pipeline

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The TiPi: Engineering and Engineering Transfer Pipeline Project is using scholarship support to recruit, retain and graduate 75 Engineering and Engineering Technology students. The financially needed, talented scholarship awardees will transfer from two-year schools into the third year at Rochester Institute of Technology. The students will be enrolled full-time in the Engineering and Engineering Technology Bachelor degree programs. The scholarship funds are supplemented by institutional financial aid intended to ensure the scholars graduate on time.

The scholar program builds on a well-established infrastructure of student support and intervention. The scholar support mechanisms identify scholars in academic jeopardy and proactively intervene on their behalf. The project's proactive student support programs could become a national model for assisting similar transfers into private institutions. The project uses co-op experiences designed to increase the probability of career success thereby impacting the scholars for a lifetime.

Periodic program assessment includes quantitative data such as grade point average and co-op salaries and qualitative data from surveys of scholars, faculty and employers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project were:

1. To address a national concern by helping to expand and diversify the engineering/technology workforce of the future
2. To develop linkages and articulations with 2-year schools and their S-STEM programs
3. To serve as a model for other highly selective universities to provide transfer students the access to the baccalaureate
4. To give participating scholars hands-on experience in the latest tools and technologies
5. To increase career opportunities and job placement rates through mandatory co-op experiences

 

To accomplish the major goals, the project had six specific objectives:

1. Recruit 25 students per year for the first three years for a total of 75 transfer students in our engineering and engineering technology programs
2. Retain at least 95% of the 75 recruited scholars, and graduate all those retained
3. Prepare the TiPi scholars for paid cooperative employment in industry or academia
4. Collect academic performance data for evaluation and assessment as well as for reporting to NSF
5. Organize one social event in each academic term except summer for TiPi scholars to meet faculty and staff
6. Place graduating scholars in a technical job in industry or in graduate school for further education

 

All of the six specific objectives have been met. The project outcomes were:

1. A total of 75 transfer students were recruited in the TiPi program meeting the desired goal.
2. A total of 4 (5%) scholars left the TiPi program before graduating from RIT resulting in a 95% retention rate.
3. 58 (77%) scholars have completed a year or more of paid cooperative employment in industry or academia. The remaining 13 (17%) scholars already have or will have completed a year or more of cooperative employment before they graduate.
4. Project information in the NSF S-STEM database is up to date as of Summer 2017. Annual reports submitted in 2013, 2014, 2015, and 2016 have been approved by NSF. Assessment and evaluation results with other relevant information were disseminated via ASEE conferences.
5. In each academic term except summer, the TiPi faculty and staff hosted a lunch get-together for the TiPi scholars, faculty and staff.
6. Of the 58 (77%) graduating scholars, 44 (59%) are in full-time position in industry or study in graduate school. The remaining 14 (19%) are reasonably certain to have a full-time position in industry in the next six months.

 


Last Modified: 07/06/2017
Modified by: Surendra K Gupta
